title: ISIS Predicts Attack on Washington, but U.S. Officials See No Evidence
content: [nytmedia id="100000004040286" crop="592" type="image"] The Islamic State terrorist group predicted an attack on Washington in a video released Monday in the wake of the deadly assault on Paris, but American counterterrorism officials said they had no intelligence pointing to the existence of a plot. Terrorist groups have used such threats against American cities in the past as propaganda to drum up fear. The Islamic State in particular has used videos spread by social media to incite violence and stoke anxieties. Counterterrorism officials say that the biggest threat inside the United States from the group, which is also known as ISIS, comes not from a 9/11-style attack launched from Syria but from Americans who are inspired by videos and decide to carry out attacks on their own. The Paris attacks prompted the F.B.I. to review its ISIS cases as a precaution, but the terrorist organization has already been a preoccupation for counterterrorism agents. This spring, the F.B.I. had so many people under surveillance for possible ties to ISIS that officials pulled agents off of other cases to help keep watch.

parent.title: Paris: Updates on the Terror Attacks Investigation

content_expanded:
The Islamic State terrorist group predicted an attack on Washington in a video released Monday in the wake of the deadly assault on Paris, but American counterterrorism officials said they had no intelligence pointing to the existence of a plot.

Terrorist groups have used such threats against American cities in the past as propaganda to drum up fear. The Islamic State in particular has used videos spread by social media to incite violence and stoke anxieties.

Counterterrorism officials say that the biggest threat inside the United States from the group, which is also known as ISIS, comes not from a 9/11-style attack launched from Syria but from Americans who are inspired by videos and decide to carry out attacks on their own.

The Paris attacks prompted the F.B.I. to review its ISIS cases as a precaution, but the terrorist organization has already been a preoccupation for counterterrorism agents.

This spring, the F.B.I. had so many people under surveillance for possible ties to ISIS that officials pulled agents off of other cases to help keep watch.

title: Loretta Lynch: U.S. Agencies Are Working With French Authorities
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004040248" crop="592" type="image"] The United States Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch made remarks on Monday about the terrorist attack in Paris. She was speaking during a news conference on an unrelated topic.
I want to begin by commenting on the horrific terrorist attack that occurred in Paris on Friday. This was a crime against civilization, and this department is committed to doing everything within our power to assist our French law enforcement colleagues in bringing those responsible to justice. I spoke with the president and his national security team at the White House on Saturday prior to his visit to the G-20 summit. Justice Department attorneys, the F.B.I., and other agencies are currently working with French authorities through our international legal assistance channels to obtain further information that may be relevant to the attacks. And we are working on an expedited basis to ensure that our Office of Justice for Victims of Overseas Terrorism is available to assist any American victims and their families. As this work goes on, we will continue to stand in solidarity with France, just as France has so often stood with us. Our thoughts and prayers are with the victims and their loved ones at this heartbreaking and immensely difficult time.

parent.title: Paris: Updates on the Terror Attacks Investigation

content_expanded:
The United States Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch made remarks on Monday about the terrorist attack in Paris. She was speaking during a news conference on an unrelated topic.

I want to begin by commenting on the horrific terrorist attack that occurred in Paris on Friday. This was a crime against civilization, and this department is committed to doing everything within our power to assist our French law enforcement colleagues in bringing those responsible to justice.

I spoke with the president and his national security team at the White House on Saturday prior to his visit to the G-20 summit. Justice Department attorneys, the F.B.I., and other agencies are currently working with French authorities through our international legal assistance channels to obtain further information that may be relevant to the attacks.

And we are working on an expedited basis to ensure that our Office of Justice for Victims of Overseas Terrorism is available to assist any American victims and their families. As this work goes on, we will continue to stand in solidarity with France, just as France has so often stood with us.

Our thoughts and prayers are with the victims and their loved ones at this heartbreaking and immensely difficult time.

title: Climate Summit in Paris Will Go Ahead Sans the Hoopla
content: [nytmedia id="100000004040230" crop="592" type="image"] Prime Minister Manuel Valls of France said on the radio on Monday that the global summit on climate issues, scheduled to begin in Paris on Nov. 30, will go ahead as planned — but many of the side events and celebrations surrounding it will not. “We are currently looking into it," Mr. Valls told RTL, the radio station. "But anything that was exterior to the COP — a whole range of concerts and of rather festive events — will no doubt be cancelled.” COP is shorthand for the summit, known formally as the United Nations Conference on Climate Change. Mr. Valls insisted that despite everything, “Paris will be the capital of the world” during the meeting. Though the conference is scheduled to last for 12 days, most attention will be focused on the opening day, when a number of national leaders will be on hand. “No head of state or government has asked us to postpone" the conference, Mr. Valls noted. "On the contrary, they all want to be there. Otherwise, we would be surrendering to terrorism.” He said the organizers of the Global March for Climate, a major demonstration planned for the day before the conference, were meeting on Monday to decide what to do. He suggested that the need for the French security forces to add to their protection for the summit may make it impossible to hold the march safely.

parent.title: Paris: Updates on the Terror Attacks Investigation

content_expanded:
Prime Minister Manuel Valls of France said on the radio on Monday that the global summit on climate issues, scheduled to begin in Paris on Nov. 30, will go ahead as planned — but many of the side events and celebrations surrounding it will not.

“We are currently looking into it,” Mr. Valls told RTL, the radio station. “But anything that was exterior to the COP — a whole range of concerts and of rather festive events — will no doubt be cancelled.” COP is shorthand for the summit, known formally as the United Nations Conference on Climate Change.

Mr. Valls insisted that despite everything, “Paris will be the capital of the world” during the meeting. Though the conference is scheduled to last for 12 days, most attention will be focused on the opening day, when a number of national leaders will be on hand.

“No head of state or government has asked us to postpone” the conference, Mr. Valls noted. “On the contrary, they all want to be there. Otherwise, we would be surrendering to terrorism.”

He said the organizers of the Global March for Climate, a major demonstration planned for the day before the conference, were meeting on Monday to decide what to do. He suggested that the need for the French security forces to add to their protection for the summit may make it impossible to hold the march safely.

title: Hollande Says ‘France Is at War’
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004040161" crop="592" type="image"]

President François Hollande told a joint session of Parliament on Monday that "France is at war," and that it will prevail in its fight againsy the militants of the Islamic State.

He said that the Islamic militants had targeted France because it is, "a country of freedom, because we are the homeland of human rights."

"Our democracy has prevailed over much more formidable opponents than these cowardly assassins," Mr. Hollande said. "Our Republic is not within the reach of despicable killers."

In his speech at the Château of Versailles a day after launching major airstrikes against ISIS in Syria, Mr. Hollande drew a sharp distinction between the terrorists who killed at least 129 people in coordinated attacks last Friday and the French efforts to defeat ISIS.

"We are not in a war of civilizations, because these assassins don't represent one," Mr. Hollande said. "We are in a war against jihadist terrorism, which threatens the entire world."

Mr. Hollande listed some of the names of the victims of the attacks on Friday, noting that many were under the age of 30. 

"What was their only crime? That they were alive."

The attacks were planned in Syria, organized in Belgium and carried out with the complicity of French citizens, Mr. Hollande said, noting the terrorists attacked France for its role in "fighting against terrorism in the Middle East."

The French president listed the sites of other deadly attacks carried out by ISIS this year, including Denmark, Tunisia, Lebanon, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Turkey and Libya, in addition to "daily" massacres in Syria and Iraq.

"That is why the necessity to destroy Daesh is an issue that concerns all of the international community," he said. "I have therefore asked the Security Council to convene as quickly as possible to adopt a resolution demonstrating this common will to fight against terrorism."

parent.title: Paris: Updates on the Terror Attacks Investigation

content_expanded:
President François Hollande told a joint session of Parliament on Monday that “France is at war,” and that it will prevail in its fight againsy the militants of the Islamic State.

He said that the Islamic militants had targeted France because it is, “a country of freedom, because we are the homeland of human rights.”

“Our democracy has prevailed over much more formidable opponents than these cowardly assassins,” Mr. Hollande said. “Our Republic is not within the reach of despicable killers.”

In his speech at the Château of Versailles a day after launching major airstrikes against ISIS in Syria, Mr. Hollande drew a sharp distinction between the terrorists who killed at least 129 people in coordinated attacks last Friday and the French efforts to defeat ISIS.

“We are not in a war of civilizations, because these assassins don’t represent one,” Mr. Hollande said. “We are in a war against jihadist terrorism, which threatens the entire world.”

Mr. Hollande listed some of the names of the victims of the attacks on Friday, noting that many were under the age of 30.

“What was their only crime? That they were alive.”

The attacks were planned in Syria, organized in Belgium and carried out with the complicity of French citizens, Mr. Hollande said, noting the terrorists attacked France for its role in “fighting against terrorism in the Middle East.”

The French president listed the sites of other deadly attacks carried out by ISIS this year, including Denmark, Tunisia, Lebanon, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Turkey and Libya, in addition to “daily” massacres in Syria and Iraq.

“That is why the necessity to destroy Daesh is an issue that concerns all of the international community,” he said. “I have therefore asked the Security Council to convene as quickly as possible to adopt a resolution demonstrating this common will to fight against terrorism.”

title: Israel Responds to Remark by Sweden’s Foreign Minister on Radicalization and Paris
content: [nytmedia id="100000004040121" crop="592" type="image"] Israel summoned the Swedish ambassador there to its foreign ministry on Monday to clarify his foreign minister’s remarks suggesting that Palestinian hopelessness was connected to the terrorism that struck Paris. Emmanuel Nahshon, Israel’s foreign ministry spokesman, called the comments by Margaret Wallstrom, Sweden’s foreign minister, “appallingly impudent” and accused her of being “consistently biased against Israel.” “Whoever fatuously attempts to create a link between radical Islamist attacks and the current situation between Israel and the Palestinians,” Mr. Nahshon said in a statement, “is fooling himself, his people and international public opinion.” Ms. Wallstrom, in a weekend interview on Swedish public television, mentioned the Palestinians as an example when discussing root causes of radicalization. “To counteract the radicalization, we must go back to the situation, such as the one in the Middle East of which not the least the Palestinians see that there is not future,” she said, according to a translation by the news site Times of Israel. “We must either accept a desperate situation or resort to violence.” An American-born Swede living in Israel, David Metzler, wrote about the remarks in a blog post on the news site on Sunday, calling them foolish, severe, irresponsible and mind-boggling. Ms. Wallstrom “has managed to internalize the analysis of the situation as seen by the Islamists themselves,” Mr. Metzler said. Sweden has increasingly become a leading European supporter of the Palestinians, straining its relations with Israel. Last October, it was the first Western European nation to officially recognize the state of Palestine, and in February, the Palestinians opened an embassy in Stockholm, their first in Western Europe. On Twitter, Shurat HaDin, an Israeli law firm and advocacy group, reacted to Ms. Wallstrom’s statement by asking, “Remind me again why we maintain diplomatic relations?” But the Swedish embassy in Tel Aviv said in its own Twitter post that the foreign minister had “not said that Israeli Palestinian conflict is linked to tragic events in Paris. Sweden condemns all acts of terrorism.” Erik Wirkensjo, Ms. Wallstrom’s press secretary, said in a telephone interview that her quote about the Palestinians was “completely taken out of context” from a 15 or 20 minute discussion. “She never mentioned Israel,” he noted. “She simply said that radicalization is a problem, of course, and living in conflict can lead to radicalization." “What I’ve seen in social media, people saying Swedish foreign minister blames Israel for the attacks, this is just untrue,” the spokesman added. “This is not even close to anything that she said.”

parent.title: Paris: Updates on the Terror Attacks Investigation

content_expanded:
Israel summoned the Swedish ambassador there to its foreign ministry on Monday to clarify his foreign minister’s remarks suggesting that Palestinian hopelessness was connected to the terrorism that struck Paris.

Emmanuel Nahshon, Israel’s foreign ministry spokesman, called the comments by Margaret Wallstrom, Sweden’s foreign minister, “appallingly impudent” and accused her of being “consistently biased against Israel.”

“Whoever fatuously attempts to create a link between radical Islamist attacks and the current situation between Israel and the Palestinians,” Mr. Nahshon said in a statement, “is fooling himself, his people and international public opinion.”

Ms. Wallstrom, in a weekend interview on Swedish public television, mentioned the Palestinians as an example when discussing root causes of radicalization.

“To counteract the radicalization, we must go back to the situation, such as the one in the Middle East of which not the least the Palestinians see that there is not future,” she said, according to a translation by the news site Times of Israel. “We must either accept a desperate situation or resort to violence.”

An American-born Swede living in Israel, David Metzler, wrote about the remarks in a blog post on the news site on Sunday, calling them foolish, severe, irresponsible and mind-boggling. Ms. Wallstrom “has managed to internalize the analysis of the situation as seen by the Islamists themselves,” Mr. Metzler said.

Sweden has increasingly become a leading European supporter of the Palestinians, straining its relations with Israel. Last October, it was the first Western European nation to officially recognize the state of Palestine, and in February, the Palestinians opened an embassy in Stockholm, their first in Western Europe.

On Twitter, Shurat HaDin, an Israeli law firm and advocacy group, reacted to Ms. Wallstrom’s statement by asking, “Remind me again why we maintain diplomatic relations?”

But the Swedish embassy in Tel Aviv said in its own Twitter post that the foreign minister had “not said that Israeli Palestinian conflict is linked to tragic events in Paris. Sweden condemns all acts of terrorism.”

Erik Wirkensjo, Ms. Wallstrom’s press secretary, said in a telephone interview that her quote about the Palestinians was “completely taken out of context” from a 15 or 20 minute discussion.

“She never mentioned Israel,” he noted. “She simply said that radicalization is a problem, of course, and living in conflict can lead to radicalization.”

“What I’ve seen in social media, people saying Swedish foreign minister blames Israel for the attacks, this is just untrue,” the spokesman added. “This is not even close to anything that she said.”

title: Eight Republican Governors Say They Oppose the Entry of Syrian Refugees
content: [nytmedia id="100000004040125" crop="592" type="image"] At least eight Republican governors have now said they oppose the entry of Syrian refugees into their states in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks in Paris. Gov. Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas announced on Twitter on Monday that he opposed settling refugees from Syria in his state. Here is his full statement. https://twitter.com/AsaHutchinson/status/666281290883166208 Gov. Charlie Baker of Massachusetts said Monday morning that he opposed letting Syrian refugees into the state until the federal government decided how to deal with them. "No, I'm not interested in accepting refugees from Syria," he told reporters at the Statehouse. "I'm going to set the bar really high," he said. "My view on this is that the safety and security of the people of the commonwealth of Mass is my highest priority." He said he had had no conversations yet with federal officials, but added: "We would have to be very cautious about accepting folks without knowing a lot more about what the federal government's plan looks like and how it would actually be implemented and executed on." Mayor Martin J. Walsh of Boston, a Democrat, who was standing next to Mr. Baker as they emerged from a legislative hearing, agreed with his approach. "I stand with the governor," the mayor said, adding, "we would have to see the vetting process." Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas released a letter on Monday addressed to President Obama, saying that Texas “will not accept any refugees from Syria” because of security concerns. “And I urge you, as president, to halt your plans to allow Syrians to be resettled anywhere in the United States.” The Obama administration has said that it intends to allow up to 10,000 refugees from Syria into the country. Gov. Phil Bryant of Mississippi said that he vowed to do "everything humanly possible" to block refugees from entering his state. Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana said in a statement on Monday that all state agencies will immediately suspend resettlement of refugees from Syria. And Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana, a candidate for president, issued an executive order "to prevent the resettlement of Syrian refugees in the State of Louisiana." In Michigan, Gov. Rick Snyder said on Sunday that the state would freeze its efforts to accept refugees until the Department of Homeland Security reviews its security procedures. In a statement on Sunday, Gov. Robert Bentley announced he was refusing the relocation of Syrian refugees to Alabama. A Syrian passport was found near the body of one of the attackers in Paris. “After full consideration of this weekend’s attacks of terror on innocent citizens in Paris, I will oppose any attempt to relocate Syrian refugees to Alabama through the U.S. Refugee Admissions Program," he said. "As your governor, I will not stand complicit to a policy that places the citizens of Alabama in harm’s way." Whether governors have the authority to block refugees is not clear. John Barcanic, the executive director of World Relief Chicago, a refugee resettlement agency, said in an interview that governors are typically not involved with the resettlement process. “My hunch is that they don’t have the power to stop it,” he said. “It’s the Department of State who decides whether we’ll take certain kinds of refugees. Once somebody is in the country, I’m fairly certain that a governor doesn’t have the ability to stop somebody from living in their state simply because of their race.”

parent.title: Paris: Updates on the Terror Attacks Investigation

content_expanded:
At least eight Republican governors have now said they oppose the entry of Syrian refugees into their states in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks in Paris.

Gov. Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas announced on Twitter on Monday that he opposed settling refugees from Syria in his state. Here is his full statement.

As Governor I will oppose Syrian refugees being relocated to Arkansas.

— Gov. Asa Hutchinson (@AsaHutchinson) November 16, 2015

Gov. Charlie Baker of Massachusetts said Monday morning that he opposed letting Syrian refugees into the state until the federal government decided how to deal with them.

“No, I’m not interested in accepting refugees from Syria,” he told reporters at the Statehouse. “I’m going to set the bar really high,” he said. “My view on this is that the safety and security of the people of the commonwealth of Mass is my highest priority.”

He said he had had no conversations yet with federal officials, but added: “We would have to be very cautious about accepting folks without knowing a lot more about what the federal government’s plan looks like and how it would actually be implemented and executed on.”

Mayor Martin J. Walsh of Boston, a Democrat, who was standing next to Mr. Baker as they emerged from a legislative hearing, agreed with his approach.

“I stand with the governor,” the mayor said, adding, “we would have to see the vetting process.”

Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas released a letter on Monday addressed to President Obama, saying that Texas “will not accept any refugees from Syria” because of security concerns. “And I urge you, as president, to halt your plans to allow Syrians to be resettled anywhere in the United States.”

The Obama administration has said that it intends to allow up to 10,000 refugees from Syria into the country.

Gov. Phil Bryant of Mississippi said that he vowed to do “everything humanly possible” to block refugees from entering his state.

Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana said in a statement on Monday that all state agencies will immediately suspend resettlement of refugees from Syria. And Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana, a candidate for president, issued an executive order “to prevent the resettlement of Syrian refugees in the State of Louisiana.”

In Michigan, Gov. Rick Snyder said on Sunday that the state would freeze its efforts to accept refugees until the Department of Homeland Security reviews its security procedures.

In a statement on Sunday, Gov. Robert Bentley announced he was refusing the relocation of Syrian refugees to Alabama. A Syrian passport was found near the body of one of the attackers in Paris.

“After full consideration of this weekend’s attacks of terror on innocent citizens in Paris, I will oppose any attempt to relocate Syrian refugees to Alabama through the U.S. Refugee Admissions Program,” he said. “As your governor, I will not stand complicit to a policy that places the citizens of Alabama in harm’s way.”

Whether governors have the authority to block refugees is not clear.

John Barcanic, the executive director of World Relief Chicago, a refugee resettlement agency, said in an interview that governors are typically not involved with the resettlement process.

“My hunch is that they don’t have the power to stop it,” he said. “It’s the Department of State who decides whether we’ll take certain kinds of refugees. Once somebody is in the country, I’m fairly certain that a governor doesn’t have the ability to stop somebody from living in their state simply because of their race.”

title: Museums Reopen in Paris Three Days After Terrorist Attacks
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004040005" crop="592" type="image"]


Three days after a string of terrorist attacks shook the Paris area, major cultural institutions such as the Louvre and Musée d'Orsay reopened to the public on Monday after being closed for the weekend as part of a general state of emergency.
 
Museums, movie theaters and some tourist sites were hoping to return to normal, despite continuing security concerns in the city. The museums reopened their doors at 1 p.m.
 
But the attack on a popular concert hall, the Bataclan, where 89 people were killed while attending a concert by the rock band Eagles of Death Metal, appears to have chilled the music scene in Paris. Artists like Marilyn Manson and the hard rock group, Papa Roach, canceled concerts scheduled Monday night in the Zenith and the Olympia.  Producers also temporarily suspended a French musical comedy, "Résiste," featuring the music of Michel Berger and France Gall. 
 
On Monday, France's culture minister, Fleur Pellerin, offered aid to cultural institutions that might suffer financially because of the attacks.  She announced plans for a special government fund for theaters and concert halls faced with the rising costs of increased security and a potential downturn in ticket sales. 
 
"Everything will be done so that music remains alive in our country," she said, noting that, "Culture is our greatest shield, and our artists are our best weapon."
 
Prince, Motörhead, the Foo Fighters, U2, and the Deftones canceled Paris concerts. "In light of this senseless violence, the closing of borders, and international mourning, we can't continue right now," the Foo Fighters group announced in a Facebook posting. "There is no other way to say it. This is crazy and it sucks." 
 
But at least one well known French singer, Shy'm, insisted this week that the show would go on.
 
"After much reflection, doubts and fears, I decided to go on stage," she wrote in Facebook post. "What has happened to France and humanity is unspeakable but it is out of the question to hole up and stay silent." 
 
"This," she added, "is the resistance."

parent.title: Paris: Updates on the Terror Attacks Investigation

content_expanded:
Three days after a string of terrorist attacks shook the Paris area, major cultural institutions such as the Louvre and Musée d’Orsay reopened to the public on Monday after being closed for the weekend as part of a general state of emergency.

Museums, movie theaters and some tourist sites were hoping to return to normal, despite continuing security concerns in the city. The museums reopened their doors at 1 p.m.

But the attack on a popular concert hall, the Bataclan, where 89 people were killed while attending a concert by the rock band Eagles of Death Metal, appears to have chilled the music scene in Paris. Artists like Marilyn Manson and the hard rock group, Papa Roach, canceled concerts scheduled Monday night in the Zenith and the Olympia. Producers also temporarily suspended a French musical comedy, “Résiste,” featuring the music of Michel Berger and France Gall.

On Monday, France’s culture minister, Fleur Pellerin, offered aid to cultural institutions that might suffer financially because of the attacks. She announced plans for a special government fund for theaters and concert halls faced with the rising costs of increased security and a potential downturn in ticket sales.

“Everything will be done so that music remains alive in our country,” she said, noting that, “Culture is our greatest shield, and our artists are our best weapon.”

Prince, Motörhead, the Foo Fighters, U2, and the Deftones canceled Paris concerts. “In light of this senseless violence, the closing of borders, and international mourning, we can’t continue right now,” the Foo Fighters group announced in a Facebook posting. “There is no other way to say it. This is crazy and it sucks.”

But at least one well known French singer, Shy’m, insisted this week that the show would go on.

“After much reflection, doubts and fears, I decided to go on stage,” she wrote in Facebook post. “What has happened to France and humanity is unspeakable but it is out of the question to hole up and stay silent.”

“This,” she added, “is the resistance.”

title: Obama Says U.S. and France Will Share More Intelligence
content: [nytmedia id="100000004040014" crop="592" type="video" autostart="false"] President Obama announced a new agreement on Monday between the United States and France to share more intelligence, saying that the new arrangement would "allow our personnel to pass threat information, including on ISIL, even more quickly and more often." Mr. Obama spoke after meetings here with other leders of the Group of 20 industrial and emerging countries. He said that the attacks in Paris last week stiffened the world's resolve to fight the militants of the Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL. The United States is trying to persuade its allies to become more deeply involved in the fight against ISIS, and the American effort to find more partners on the ground in Syria and Iraq is accelerating, the president said. http://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/17/world/europe/obama-says-paris-attacks-have-stiffened-resolve-to-crush-isis.html

parent.title: Paris: Updates on the Terror Attacks Investigation

content_expanded:
Photo: Susan Walsh/Associated Press; Video: By REUTERS

President Obama announced a new agreement on Monday between the United States and France to share more intelligence, saying that the new arrangement would “allow our personnel to pass threat information, including on ISIL, even more quickly and more often.”

Mr. Obama spoke after meetings here with other leders of the Group of 20 industrial and emerging countries. He said that the attacks in Paris last week stiffened the world’s resolve to fight the militants of the Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL.

The United States is trying to persuade its allies to become more deeply involved in the fight against ISIS, and the American effort to find more partners on the ground in Syria and Iraq is accelerating, the president said.

Obama Chides Republicans Who Want to Screen Muslim Refugees

By MICHAEL D. SHEAR

Speaking after the Group of 20 meeting in Turkey, the president said such suggestions are un-American. “That’s not who we are,” he said.

title: Belgian Prosecutor Says Search in Molenbeek Came Up Empty
content: [nytmedia id="100000004040015" crop="592" type="image"] Though the Belgian police scoured the Molenbeek district of Brussels for more than three hours on Monday, they found nothing and made no arrests, according to a brief statement from the federal prosecutor's office. The Molenbeek area is notorious for being a hotbed of radicalism, and a number of terrorist attacks or people connected with them have had links to the neighborhood. One of the objectives of the search on Monday was to find Salah Abdeslam, a suspect in the latest Paris attacks. Another man from the area, Abdelhamid Abaaoud, is suspected of being the mastermind of the Paris assaults. He is now believed to be in Syria. Two small explosions were heard during the police operation, and dozens of masked and heavily armed security officers sealed the area off while it was in progress, the Associated Press reported, and residents were told to stay out of harm’s way. But nothing seems to have come of the operation. "During the morning, an inspection was carried out in Molenbeek-Saint-Jean in Delaunoy Street," the statement said. "This inspection was negative and did not result in any arrests."

parent.title: Paris: Updates on the Terror Attacks Investigation

content_expanded:
Though the Belgian police scoured the Molenbeek district of Brussels for more than three hours on Monday, they found nothing and made no arrests, according to a brief statement from the federal prosecutor’s office.

The Molenbeek area is notorious for being a hotbed of radicalism, and a number of terrorist attacks or people connected with them have had links to the neighborhood.

One of the objectives of the search on Monday was to find Salah Abdeslam, a suspect in the latest Paris attacks. Another man from the area, Abdelhamid Abaaoud, is suspected of being the mastermind of the Paris assaults. He is now believed to be in Syria.

Two small explosions were heard during the police operation, and dozens of masked and heavily armed security officers sealed the area off while it was in progress, the Associated Press reported, and residents were told to stay out of harm’s way. But nothing seems to have come of the operation.

“During the morning, an inspection was carried out in Molenbeek-Saint-Jean in Delaunoy Street,” the statement said. “This inspection was negative and did not result in any arrests.”

title: C.I.A. Director Sees ‘Hallmarks’ of Islamic State in Paris Attacks
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004039953" crop="592" type="image"]

John O. Brennan, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, said on Monday morning that the Paris attacks and the recent downing of a Russian jet over the Sinai Peninsula both bear the “hallmarks” of the Islamic State.

He said that the group, which he called an “association of murderous sociopaths,” had been developing an “external operations agenda” that it has begun to implement “with lethal effect.” Mr. Brennan also said he believed that the Islamic State had more terrorist plots against the West in the works, and that it is determined to carry out what he called the group’s “external agenda.”

The Islamic State, he said during a speech at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, is “not going to content itself with violence inside the Syrian and Iraqi borders.”

Wading into the debate over surveillance, privacy and encrypted communications, the C.I.A. director said he hoped that the Paris attacks might be a “wake-up call” for Europe and the United States during a time of criticism over expansive surveillance programs. He said that “unauthorized disclosures” [read: Edward J. Snowden] and “hand-wringing” over the government’s role in disrupting terrorism have weakened the abilities of Western intelligence services to prevent attacks from groups like the Islamic State.

parent.title: Paris: Updates on the Terror Attacks Investigation

He said that the group, which he called an “association of murderous sociopaths,” had been developing an “external operations agenda” that it has begun to implement “with lethal effect.” Mr. Brennan also said he believed that the Islamic State had more terrorist plots against the West in the works, and that it is determined to carry out what he called the group’s “external agenda.”

The Islamic State, he said during a speech at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, is “not going to content itself with violence inside the Syrian and Iraqi borders.”

Wading into the debate over surveillance, privacy and encrypted communications, the C.I.A. director said he hoped that the Paris attacks might be a “wake-up call” for Europe and the United States during a time of criticism over expansive surveillance programs. He said that “unauthorized disclosures” [read: Edward J. Snowden] and “hand-wringing” over the government’s role in disrupting terrorism have weakened the abilities of Western intelligence services to prevent attacks from groups like the Islamic State.
